title: Cats. 88–89  Two Fragments of Bowls

<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Fragment of a Bowl  
Late 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 7 × 6.4 × 2.1 cm (2 3/4 × 2 1/2 × 7/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1219

Fragment of a Bowl  
Late 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 5.7 × 3.8 × 1.3 cm (2 1/4 × 1 1/2 × 1/2 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1220

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">These two fragments represent a well-known series of ribbed bowls that imitate stone vessels of agate or sardonyx. A particularly beautiful example of a banded agate amphoriskos can be found in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York (fig. 1). There are numerous examples of these fragments in many museum and private collections, including the Corning Museum of Glass, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Toledo Museum of Art. The collection of ribbed bowl fragments in Toledo is substantial; a small selection of those fragments was published by David Grose in 1989. An interesting range of color and form can be found in the Princeton University Art Museum. An example of a complete ribbed mosaic glass bowl imitating agate is in the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles (fig. 2), and a footed ribbed bowl on a base is in the Met’s collection (fig. 3). Also in the Met is a rare, complete mosaic glass bowl imitating onyx; this is a Hellenistic vessel that predates these later ribbed forms (fig. 4).  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Goldstein, Pre-Roman and Early Roman Glass, pp. 189–91, nos. 503–16, plates 26, 41.

New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, acc. nos. 91.1.1737, 91.1.1643, 91.1.1783, 91.1.1658, 91.1.1666, 81.10.154, 91.1.1799, and 91.1.1794 represent a series of plain and ribbed bowls imitating agate.

Grose, Early Ancient Glass, pp. 269–84, nos. 250–314, pp. 214–17 (color pl.), cover ribbed mosaic bowls that imitate stone as well as those that have more complex floral patterns.

Antonaras, Fire and Sand, pp. 60–61, nos. 28–29, 31–35.

Carboni et al., “Ars Vitraria”, p. 21.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, Purchase, Mr. and Mrs. Sid R. Bass Gift, in honor of Annette de la Renta, and Rogers Fund, 2001.

fig. 3 Ribbed Mosaic Glass Bowl with Base Ring, late 1st century B.C./early 1st century A.D. Roman, early imperial, probably Italian. Glass; h. 12.7 cm (5 in.). The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, Gift of J. Pierpont Morgan, 1917.

fig. 4 Mosaic Jar, 2nd/early 1st century B.C. Greek, probably eastern Mediterranean, Hellenistic. Glass; 13.8 × 15.6 cm (5 7/16 × 6 1/8 in.). The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, Edward C. Moore Collection, Bequest of Edward C. Moore, 1891.
